subject: Re: [junit] Re: Placing of Source Code
msgSnippet: ... What I usually do is starting with app classes and test classes in the same package and in the same directory tree. This facilitates browsing them together
messageBody:
> You *can* place both your source and tests in one directory.
> However, it may make final packaging more difficult. If your concern
> is package scope testing, you can still accomplish this from
> separate directories by using the same packaging in separate
> directories. For example
>
> src_java
> - com
> - somewhere
> - widget
> - MyWidget.java
> src_java_test
> - com
> - somewhere
> - widget
> -MyWidgetTest.java
>
> Since the test class is stored in a separate source tree packaging
> is easy (everything from the src_java directory). However since the
> two source trees share the same packaging you can still test down to
> the package-private scope.
>
> If you have some other reason for having your tests coesist...

What I usually do is starting with app classes and test classes in the same
package and in the same directory tree. This facilitates browsing them
together and it's the simplest thing you can do. That way the threshold value for
having too many classes in a single package is reached earlier - which is a
good thing in my opinion and forces me to rethink my package structure more
often.
I sometimes move to separate directory trees (as described above) when
approaching deployment iff there's a requirement not to deploy the test classes.

I'm yet waiting for an Eclipse view which merges two directories with the
same package into a single package. *Maybe* I'd then go with two directory
trees from the very beginning ... but probably not.

Johannes
